thread.title: Blood-stained wolfhounds battle it out in Kyrgyzstan
thread.title_full: Blood-stained wolfhounds battle it out in Kyrgyzstan

title: Blood-stained wolfhounds battle it out in Kyrgyzstan
text: comments Yelping in pain with their fur matted with blood, these shocking photographs reveal the brutality of dog fighting in Kyrgyzstan. The images were taken during a barbaric event held by a local breeders club in the capital city of Bishkek, staged with the aim of finding the dog best suited to breeding with the Asian Shepherd. Some 17 owners brought their dogs to fight for the title of 'champion of breed', with spectators gathering to watch the blood-sport competition played out. Dog-fighting competitions is not unique to Kyrgyzstan - they are also known to be held in China, where it is not widespread but there are no animal cruelty laws to prevent it from taking place. Like China, the spotlight has been shone on Kyrgyzstan for its treatment of animals, and activists are making their voices heard. Yelping in pain with their fur matted with blood, these shocking photographs reveal the brutality of dog fighting in Kyrgyzstan The images were taken during a barbaric event held by a local breeders club in the capital city of Bishkek, staged with the aim of finding the dog best suited to breeding with the Asian Shepherd Some 17 owners brought their dogs to fight for the title of 'champion of breed', with spectators gathering to watch the blood-sport competition played out Travelling aquatic circuses, which involve beluga whales and dolphins performing acrobatic stunts, still visit the country, despite being banned across much of the world. They remain popular in the ex-Soviet bloc, where forms of circus entertainment prohibited in the West, such as acts with wild animals like lions and bears, continue to thrive despite concerns about animal welfare.
